title.justification: The title is explicitly given at the beginning of the document.

extractions.description: The paper presents SNDS, an imitation learning framework that efficiently trains scalable neural policies with formal global stability guarantees. It leverages a neural architecture to jointly train a policy and its associated Lyapunov candidate to ensure stability, validated through simulations and real-world deployments on manipulator arms.

type.justification: The paper includes empirical evaluations of the proposed model, SNDS, through simulations and real-world experiments.
type.quote: We validate our approach through extensive simulations and deploy the trained policies on a real-world manipulator arm.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on imitation learning, which is evident through its goals and methodologies, such as mimicking expert behavior and learning stable policies.
name.quote: Imitation learning mitigates the resource-intensive nature of learning policies from scratch by mimicking expert behavior.

name.justification: The research focuses on learning policies that are globally stable, which is a major aspect of the presented approach, SNDS.
name.quote: SNDS leverages a neural architecture that enables the joint training of the policy and its associated Lyapunov candidate to ensure global stability throughout the learning process.

name.justification: The research includes planning globally stable trajectories as part of the policy learning.
name.quote: The optimized policy is then deployed (bottom) to plan globally stable trajectories resistant to unpredictable perturbations.

name.justification: The paper utilizes Lyapunov stability theory to ensure global stability of the trained policies.
name.quote: Providing formal stability analysis founded on Lyapunov theory and convex neural networks.

name.justification: SNDS is the primary model proposed in the paper, which includes a neural architecture for stable policy learning.
name.quote: We propose SNDS, an imitation learning approach aimed at efficient training of scalable neural policies while formally ensuring global stability.

is_contributed.justification: The SNDS is introduced and developed by the authors in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We propose SNDS, an imitation learning approach.

is_executed.justification: The paper describes the execution and deployment of SNDS through simulations and real-world scenarios.
is_executed.quote: We validate our approach through extensive simulations and deploy the trained policies on a real-world manipulator arm.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares SNDS with other baseline methods such as Behavioral Cloning, LPV-DS, and SDS-EF.
is_compared.quote: We compare our approach against three existing baselines: Behavioral Cloning (BC), Linear Parameter-Varying Dynamical System (LPV-DS), and Stable Dynamical System Learning Using Euclideanizing Flows (SDS-EF).

referenced_paper_title.justification: SNDS is a contribution of the current paper, hence there is no referenced paper title for it.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We propose SNDS, an imitation learning approach.

name.justification: The LASA Handwriting Dataset is explicitly mentioned as one of the datasets used for evaluation in the paper.
name.quote: Our primary dataset is sourced from the well-known LASA Handwriting dataset, which contains records of handwritten trajectories on a tablet.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The LASA Handwriting Dataset is used in the experiments of this paper, not referenced from another paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Handwriting Dataset [24] contains 30 sets of 2D handwriting motions recorded from a Tablet-PC via user input.

name.justification: The Messy Snake data is used for evaluating the model's performance in high-dimensional state spaces.
name.quote: We use synthetic demonstrations for orientation, as the demonstrations only comprise translation and linear velocity. After training SNDS on this data, the policy generates trajectories in SE(3) that guide the end-effector toward the desired pose.

referenced_paper_title.value: A physically-consistent bayesian non-parametric mixture model for dynamical system learning
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset is gathered as per the method described in the reference 7 of the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Messy Snake data, gathered in [7],

name.justification: The dataset is referred to as being used for training the imitation learning model, SNDS.
name.quote: provided a dataset of expert’s state-action pairs.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The Expert Demonstration Dataset is a general term for the data used to train the SNDS model, not a specific dataset from another paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: provided a dataset of expert’s state-action pairs.
